import React from 'react'; import '../Rights.css'; import Navbar from './Navbar'; import Footer from './Footer'; export default function RightI() { // Data for consistent rendering const articles = [ { id: 14, title: "Equality before law" }, { id: 15, title: "Prohibition of discrimination" }, { id: 16, title: "Equality of opportunity in public employment" }, { id: 17, title: "Abolition of untouchability" }, { id: 18, title: "Abolition of titles" } ]; const cases = [ { name: "Kesavananda Bharati v. Kerala (1973)", url: "https://indiankanoon.org/doc/123456/", impact: "Affirmed basic structure doctrine" }, { name: "Maneka Gandhi v. Union (1978)", url: "https://indiankanoon.org/doc/789012/", impact: "Broadened right to equality and personal liberty" }, { name: "Indra Sawhney v. Union (1992)", url: "https://indiankanoon.org/doc/345678/", impact: "Established 50% cap on reservations" } ]; return ( <>

Right to Equality (Articles 14–18)

Fundamental right ensuring equal protection and prohibiting discrimination

🧩 Overview

Article 14 establishes the equality before law principle, stating that "the State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws". Articles 15–18 expand this by:

  • Prohibiting discrimination on religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
  • Ensuring equal opportunity in public employment
  • Abolishing untouchability and its practice in any form
  • Prohibiting state conferment of titles except military and academic distinctions

📚 Contained Articles

{articles.map(article => (

Article {article.id}

{article.title}

))}

✨ Constitutional Importance

The Right to Equality forms the bedrock of Indian democracy by:

  • Creating a framework for social justice and affirmative action
  • Providing legal tools to combat historical discrimination
  • Ensuring equal access to public opportunities and services
  • Protecting individual dignity regardless of background

Particularly crucial for marginalized communities, it enables progressive legislation like reservation policies and anti-discrimination laws.

📜 Historical Context

This right draws from multiple influences:

  • American Constitution (14th Amendment's Equal Protection Clause)
  • French Revolution ideals of liberty, equality and fraternity
  • British Common Law concept of rule of law

Dr. B.R. Ambedkar emphasized these provisions to combat India's caste system, calling them "the heart and soul of the Constitution."

🏛️ Landmark Judgments

{courtCase.name}

{courtCase.impact}

))}

Test Your Knowledge

); }
